awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Hardware and Embedded Systems Security and Trust (RHEST)
awd_abstract_narration:
This funding establishes a new Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at the University of Cincinnati. This REU site will host ten undergraduate students for ten summer weeks each year to work on research projects in the area of hardware and embedded systems security and trust. The security and trust of hardware and embedded systems play increasingly critical roles in building secure, reliable, and trustworthy computing systems, communication networks, and cyberinfrastructures. The students will work closely with faculty mentors, advance their knowledge and hands-on skills in hardware and embedded systems security and trust, and develop professional skills for their future careers in computing. The site will attract undergraduate students across the nation, particularly focusing on recruiting students from underrepresented groups in computing and institutions with limited research opportunities in computing. 

The REU research projects cover critical and emerging research problems in hardware and embedded systems security and trust, including side-channel attacks, fault injection attacks, reserve engineering, security validation of third-party intellectual properties, and detection of hardware Trojans. The goal of the research projects is to defend against (or mitigate) attacks, minimize information leakage, and strengthen the security and trust of hardware and embedded systems. The research findings of this project will promote workforce development in cybersecurity, increase the economic competitiveness of the U.S. in hardware and embedded systems, and enhance national security.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this NSF project, the team established a new Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site, named RHEST -- Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Hardware and Embedded Systems Security and Trust. This REU Site is hosted by the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) in the College of Engineering and Applied Science (CEAS) at the University of Cincinnati (UC) in Cincinnati, Ohio. From Summer 2022 to Summer 2024, this REU Site received 297 applications (2022: 54; 2023: 80, 2024: 163) through the NSF ETAP website. Our REU Site has directly supported 30 undergraduate students (from 18 universities) to participate in research in hardware and embedded system security. Specifically, the students worked on research projects related to side-channel analysis, FPGA reverse engineering, benchmark generation for hardware security and verification, hardware Trojan detection, binary analysis, and adversarial machine learning.

Our REU Site provided valuable research experience and professional training to these students to promote their knowledge and skills in computing. Our REU Site aims to advance knowledge and strengthen workforce development in hardware and embedded system security (as well as cybersecurity in general). In addition, another 4 undergraduate students were supported by other funding sources (e.g., REU supplement and LSAMP program) and participated in our REU Site activities.  

Among the 30 students, who were directly supported by this award, 17 students (57%) were from institutions with limited research opportunities in Electrical Engineering, Computer Engineering, and Computer Science. 13 students (43%) were from underrepresented groups in STEM (including seven female, four African Americans, three Hispanics, three with disabilities). 10 students (33%) have published research papers at peer-reviewed conferences. Four students have presented their research findings at national and international conferences. In addition, many students had the opportunity to present their research findings to industrial partners from the NSF IUCRC Center in Hardware and Embedded System Security and Trust.

As of Spring 2025, among the 22 students who have graduated or are graduating from their home institutions, nine students have applied to graduate schools and seven of them are pursuing graduate degrees (4 pursuing doctorate degrees and 3 pursuing master's degrees). Three students have received prestigious fellowships, such as the NSF CyberCorps Scholarship for Services Fellowship. Ten students have received internship positions and full-time job offers in the area of cybersecurity, including leading technology companies (e.g., Apple), national labs (e.g., Sandia National Laboratories and MIT Lincoln Laboratories), and major defense companies (e.g., Booz Allen and MITRE).
